rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 144: Line 144:
==Modern times==
==Modern times==
â
[[Image:Hilary_Putnam.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Hilary Putnam]] [[Image:Rorty.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Richard Rorty.]]
+
[[Image:Hilary_Putnam.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Hilary Putnam]]
Towards the end of the 20th century there was a resurgence of interest in pragmatism. Largely responsible for this are [[Hilary Putnam]] and [[Richard Rorty]]. Rorty is famous as the author of ''[[Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature]]'' and ''[[Philosophy and Social Hope]]''. Hilary Putnam is well known for his [[quasi-empiricism in mathematics]]<ref>[[Hilary Putnam|Putnam, Hilary]], 1975, ''Mind, Language, and Reality. Philosophical Papers, Volume 2''. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. ISBN 88-459-0257-9</ref>, his challenge of the [[brain in a vat]] [[thought experiment]]<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/brain-vat/ "Brains in a Vat" at the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy] Retrieved September 10, 2009</ref>, and his other work in [[philosophy of mind]], [[philosophy of language]], and [[philosophy of science]].
Towards the end of the 20th century there was a resurgence of interest in pragmatism. Largely responsible for this are [[Hilary Putnam]] and [[Richard Rorty]]. Rorty is famous as the author of ''[[Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature]]'' and ''[[Philosophy and Social Hope]]''. Hilary Putnam is well known for his [[quasi-empiricism in mathematics]]<ref>[[Hilary Putnam|Putnam, Hilary]], 1975, ''Mind, Language, and Reality. Philosophical Papers, Volume 2''. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. ISBN 88-459-0257-9</ref>, his challenge of the [[brain in a vat]] [[thought experiment]]<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/brain-vat/ "Brains in a Vat" at the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy] Retrieved September 10, 2009</ref>, and his other work in [[philosophy of mind]], [[philosophy of language]], and [[philosophy of science]].
